hints.content: Start by understanding the movement on the x-axis. You begin at the river located at x = -1 and need to walk to each plant at x = i. Make sure to count the steps taken to reach each plant.
Consider how much water you have after watering each plant. You need to keep track of the remaining water in your can after watering, as this will determine if you need to return to the river.
Think about the conditions under which you need to return to the river. Specifically, if the remaining water is less than the amount needed for the next plant, you must return to refill.
When returning to the river, remember that it takes steps to go back. Calculate the total steps needed for both the return trip and the trip to the next plant.
You can create a variable to keep track of the total steps taken. Initialize it to zero and update it as you move to each plant and back to the river.
As you iterate through the plants, check if the current water level allows you to water the next plant. If not, add the steps to return to the river and refill before proceeding.
Donâ€™t forget to account for the initial trip to the first plant. You need to walk from the river to the first plant before watering it.
Consider edge cases, such as when the capacity of the watering can is less than the amount needed for the first plant. This will require an immediate return to the river.
After watering each plant, update the water level in your can. If you water a plant that requires more water than you have, ensure you calculate the return trip correctly.
Finally, your function should return the total number of steps taken after watering all plants. Make sure to include all steps, both to and from the river, as well as between the plants.

questionNotes: Each plant needs a specific amount of water, 1 <= plants[i] <= 10^6
Capacity of the watering can: max(plants[i]) <= capacity <= 10^9
You start at the river (x = -1) and must move to each plant in order.
